column3: Highland is the largest of Scotland's local government areas. Stretching from Appin on Loch Linnhe in the south to the northern tip of Caithness and from the island of Skye in the west to Strathspey in the east
column4: Highland Council Area encompasses the North West Highlands of Scotland
column5: some of the islands of the Inner Hebrides and a deeply indented fjord-like coastline. Bisected by the Great Glen Fault
column6: within which lies the Caledonian Canal and Loch Ness
column7: the area includes some of the oldest rocks in Scotland and a landscape dominated by mountain and moorland. Britain's highest mountain
column9: rises to the east of Fort William near the southern end of the region. Less than 2.5 per cent of the land
column10: mostly in Caithness and Easter Ross
column11: is devoted to arable farming while more than 26 per cent comprises heather moorland and peatland. While the Gulf stream on the northwest coast creates a surprisingly mild climate
column13: 500 mm in the west to less than 500 mm in the east.  This is one of the least populated regions of Europe having less than 10 inhabitants per square kilometre
column14: a consequence of the hard environment combined with land clearance and emigration during the 18th and 19th centuries. Inverness
column16: is a fast growing commercial centre in addition to being the administrative centre of the council area. Other centres of population include
column33: Lochalsh and Portree. Created in 1975 as Highland Region
column34: the present single tier Council area dates from local government reorganisation in 1996.
